summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Nevada today entered a final judgment against Nevada Secretary of State Barbara C. Cegavske and her husband, Gary Hamilton, in an emergency action to halt the implementation of the all-mail election.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Las Vegas, Nevada, alleges that, under the direction of the Secretary, she issued an emergency order halting mail-in voting in advance of the June 9, 2020 Nevada primary.  According to the SEC's order, the Secretary issued the emergency order on March 24, 2020, ordering the Secretary to implement a new, more stringent, and expedited all-electoral rule that would prevent fraud in the state's elections.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the secretary consented to the court's order.  In a parallel action, the U. S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York today announced criminal charges against the defendants.  To learn more about mail-out voting, see Litigation Release No. 5, No. 13, and No. 17 of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Rules 10b-5, 13a-1, and 14a-11 thereunder.  For more information on mailout voting and related issues, see Rule 5, 13b2-1 and 13a2-2. Â The SEC's Office of Inspector General has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment in an investment using the free and simple search tool onÂ Securities.gov.Â In a related matter, the SEC today announced that it has obtained an emergency court order halting all mail-off voting in Nevada.  On March 26, 2019, the court issued a temporary restraining order against the Defendants from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act"), Section 17(a)(1) and Rule 17a-3 thereunder, and Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) ofÂ SEC RuleÂ 8. The court also issued an order suspending the issuance of an SEC order prohibiting the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security-related documents in violation of the federal securities laws, including the right to apply for a penny stock and to participate in any federal election, including one that is subject to court approval.  Additionally, the Court granted the SEC request for a preliminary injunction against mailing, and ordered the Secretary and the Washoe County Registrar to comply with the court order.
